awd_titl_txt: Experimental Evolution of Insect Nuptial Food Gifts and Female Responses
awd_abstract_narration:
Insects have an enormous economic impact on society, negatively through their roles as agricultural pests and transmitters of disease, and positively as critical pollinators of a wide range of agricultural products. Their influence is amplified by their ability to reproduce rapidly and in great numbers, which is determined by the number of offspring each female can produce. Differences between females in their reproduction is partially controlled by males, who can manipulate females by transferring chemicals that influence their physiology and receptivity during mating. This project involves fundamental research to identify the chemicals transferred by males that influence female mating behavior, the underlying genes, and the mechanisms by which females protect themselves from these substances. These studies may lead to products that inhibit female reproduction, and which can be used for safe and effective biological control of insects. The project will also contribute to the training of the next generation of scientists by supporting undergraduate, graduate, and post-doctoral students. These students will disseminate their work through scientific scholarship, and will participate in community outreach programs centered on the public's fascination with insects. These include activities that foster an interest in science in elementary-school children and that enhance scientific literacy by providing resources for the study of insects to high school teachers. 

Nuptial food gifts are food items given by males to females and are an integral feature of various insect mating systems. In decorated crickets, nuptial food gifts take the form of a spermatophylax, a gelatinous mass forming part of the male's spermatophore and consumed by the female. Although nuptial gifts advance the fitness interests of males by maximizing sperm transfer, their effect on the fitness of females remains unclear. The researchers will employ experimental evolution to explore the role of conflicting male and female goals in driving the evolution of the chemical composition of male nuptial gifts and female responses to them in decorated crickets. Specifically, they will vary the intensity of selection and conflict by manipulating the ratio of males and females in replicate populations, and then monitor, simultaneously, the evolutionary responses of males and females. They will use gas chromatography and mass spectrometry to track evolutionary modifications in the free amino acid profile of the spermatophylax, and targeted gene expression to assess changes in key genes. Female evolutionary responses will be assessed using behavioral assays to assess the gustatory appeal of gifts, and a comparative transcriptomics approach will be used to characterize differential gene expression in brain and gut tissue of females from different selection lines. By coupling a powerful experimental evolution design with state-of-the art functional genomics, they aim to provide one of the most comprehensive examinations of how selection and conflict contribute to the evolution of a widespread reproductive adaptation in insects.

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report

Nuptial food gifts comprise materials other than sperm that are offered by males to females at copulation, and are an integral feature of the mating systems of a wide variety of insects. A pervasive feature of the majority of these gifts is that they afford the male direct access to the female's physiology. Although in some cases such gifts may represent a form of nutritional investment in females, an alternative hypothesis focuses on a more sinister purpose: nuptial food "gifts" may represent a vehicle by which males manipulate female physiology in a manner commensurate with males' fitness interests, even at a cost to females. This hypothesis predicts that the chemical composition of nuptial food gifts and females' responses to them should be driven by a fundamental sexual conflict over the paternity of a female's offspring.

We employed an experimental evolution approach to test this hypothesis in decorated crickets, Gryllodes sigillatus. Experimental evolution offers a powerful means of probing the influence of sexual conflict on the evolution of nuptial gifts because the intensity of sexual conflict is easily altered through manipulation of the adult sex ratio. In decorated crickets, nuptial food gifts take the form of a spermatophylax, a gelatinous mass forming part of the male's spermatophore and consumed by the female after mating. Spermatophylax feeding deters the female from prematurely removing the sperm-containing portion of the spermatophore (ampulla), and thus serves to entice females into relinquishing some of their control over the insemination process. Males benefit most when their gifts are fully consumed because it is under these circumstances that sperm transfer is maximized, but females often discard the spermatophylax prior to its complete consumption, creating a sexual conflict over the use of the male's sperm.

In studies supported by the award, we varied the intensity of sexual conflict by manipulating the adult sex ratio in replicate populations, and then monitored, simultaneously, the evolutionary responses of males and females after 25 generations. We used gas chromatography and mass spectrometry to track evolutionary modifications in the free amino acid profile of the spermatophylax, and targeted gene expression to assess changes in protein content. Female evolutionary responses were assessed using behavioral assays to measure the gustatory appeal of gifts, and a comparative transcriptomics approach was used to characterize differential gene expression in males and females from the different selection regimes.

Our studies yielded several lines of evidence consistent with the hypothesis that sexual conflict plays a central role in the coevolution of male nuptial gifts and female responses to these gifts in decorated crickets:

1) Males evolving in male-biased populations produced heavier food gifts with a more manipulative combination of free amino acids than those evolving in female-biased populations. Across populations, female feeding duration increased with both the mass and manipulative combination of free amino acids in the spermatophylax suggesting ongoing sexually antagonistic coevolution in these populations.

2) studies using RNA interference to knockdown expression of genes coding for proteins unique to the nuptial gift revealed significant effects on both male and female behavior. Males whose gifts lacked the most common protein (SPX1) required significantly more time to mate and exhibited lower mating success than control males. Females took significantly less time to consume gifts of SPX1 males and, consequently, males producing these gifts suffered reduced sperm transfer. A double knockdown of two additional genes in males (SPX4 and SPX6) resulted in a reduction in the duration of gift feeding in females.

3) RNA sequencing data from male and female reproductive tissue revealed more than 300 differentially expressed genes between the reproductive organs of virgin females from the male-biased selection regime, when compared with these organs of virgins from the female-biased regime.

4) a comparative transcriptomics study revealed that nuptial feeding by females leads to the differential expression of genes in both head and gut tissue. A gene co-expression network analysis in the head tissue revealed that both sperm transfer and the consumption of the spermatophylax induce their own distinct patterns of gene expression, and that it is the content of the spermatophylax per se rather than the act of feeding itself that influences gene expression.

The project provided scientific training to one postdoctoral fellow, seven graduate students, and six undergraduate students, and provided research opportunities to a high school teacher and three high school students. The PIs and their graduate students participated in multiple outreach programs, including programs involving high school students in research, recruitment of underrepresented minority students, enhancement of elementary school teachers' training in science, and efforts to enhance the science curriculum in middle and high schools. Collaborative research with scientists at the USDA identified several viruses causing high mortality in crickets, which could greatly inform rearing practices in large-scale commercial cricket rearing operations.
